awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Electrostatic Design for Cold-Cathode, Miniature X-ray Sources
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is improved access to 3D x-ray imaging in everyday life. Currently 3D x-ray imaging is used for applications where it is absolutely necessary to non-destructively image an object. One example is in healthcare, known as computed tomography, where imaging is performed 250,000 times per day in the US saving countless lives by enabling doctors to quickly identify and treat disease such as stroke, heart attack, and cancer. Airports are other locations where computed tomography is heavily used to quickly inspect millions of bags per day to catch threats that were once unable to be seen through conventional x-ray systems. The systems capable of 3D x-ray imaging for the applications mentioned above are large, expensive and immobile which prevent their use in more applications. This project enables a new architecture for 3D x-ray imaging which promises to make systems less expensive, smaller and more compact, require less power and demonstrate higher performance. This new architecture will enable access to 3D x-ray imaging for new applications by making it more affordable and available where and when it is needed, outside of key infrastructure locations like hospitals and airports.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the first step in developing the most critical component to a new 3D x-ray imaging architecture: a miniature, high-performance, and inexpensive x-ray source. Modern 3D x-ray imaging systems are large, expensive and immobile due to the method of generating 3D images. A single x-ray source and detector arc pair are rotated at high speeds to generate 2D images at different angles which are used to reconstruct a 3D model. Modern x-ray sources and detectors are very bulky, weighing over 100 pounds each, and necessitate substantial structural reinforcement, resulting in systems that weigh over 1000 pounds. The proposed new architecture uses a stationary ring of x-ray sources and detectors. The x-ray sources are electrically turned on and off mimicking the rotation of modern 3D x-ray imaging systems without spinning, resulting in a system that is inexpensive and smaller, and uses lower power while demonstrating higher performance. For these aspirations to be realized, a miniature x-ray source that is smaller, high-performance and inexpensive must be developed. This project will take the first steps to characterize such an x-ray source by measuring key metrics such as the performance, resolution and reliability.  The design will be iterated through simulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
X-Sight’s mission is to develop key technologies that improve US healthcare, security and the competitiveness of US manufacturing industries. Using NSF SBIR Phase I funding, X-Sight has demonstrated a key enabling technology for accessible and affordable next-generation 3D x-ray imaging, known as computed tomography (CT).

X-Sight was funded by NSF under a SBIR Phase I program to enable next generation 3D x-ray CT imaging systems that are light-weight, compact, portable, and have low cost-of-ownership. Conventional CT systems rely on mechanically rotating a single large, bulky gantry (>1000 pounds) that consists of an x-ray generating source and an x-ray detector (like a camera) around an object to take images at different angles to reconstruct a 3D model. X-Sight’s new architecture uses a stationary ring of x-ray sources and detectors. The x-ray sources are electrically turned on and off to take images, mimicking the rotation of modern CT systems without spinning, resulting in a system that is inexpensive, smaller, and has a lower cost of ownership. These proposed stationary CT systems can address unmet needs for the medical, security and manufacturing industries that cannot be addressed today. For such system to be realized, a miniature x-ray source that is small, high-performance and inexpensive is required. Such miniature x-ray source technology does not exist today.

 

Using NSF SBIR Phase I funding, X-Sight experimentally demonstrated the enabling component for aspirational next generation portable, accessible, high performance, and inexpensive x-ray CT systems. X-Sight demonstrated the world’s first proof-of-concept miniature x-ray source that could feasibly meet size, weight, performance, and cost requirements for next generation CT systems. X-Sight’s miniature x-ray source built for NSF SBIR Phase I could have as high performance as conventional x-ray sources while being >20x smaller and >50x lighter. X-Sight’s x-ray source is the world’s first x-ray source that uses silicon field emission technology that was developed by university research in the USA. NSF SBIR Phase I funding enabled X-Sight to demo full x-ray imaging using this new miniature x-ray source technology to medical and security CT systems manufacturers. Additionally, using NSF SBIR Phase I funding, X-Sight designed and simulated the additional components needed to build a commercial miniature x-ray source and has determined it is feasible to fit the components in x-ray source dimensions required for next generation portable, light-weight CT systems. X-Sight is the only USA based company commercializing miniature x-ray sources using field emission technology to enable these new CT imaging systems. NSF SBIR Phase I funding has enabled X-Sight to complete the first step of demonstrating component feasibility for building the next generation portable, accessible, and affordable CT systems. Thus, NSF enabled X-Sight to make substantial progress in its mission to provide new accessible, affordable, and highest performance 3D x-ray imaging to improve national health, security, and manufacturing.

The broader impact of X-Sight’s NSF SBIR Phase I results is to improve the USA’s healthcare, security and the competitiveness of its manufacturing. Medical CT is used 250,000 times per day to save countless lives by enabling doctors to quickly identify and treat diseases such as stroke, heart attack, and cancer. At airports, security CT is used to scan millions of bags per day to catch threats and keep the world’s transport infrastructure safe. In manufacturing, CT is used to identify and understand defects during product assembly and fabrication.

Currently, broader accessibility and affordability of CT imaging is restricted by existing CT imaging systems which are large, expensive, bulky (>3000 pounds for entire system), and need structural reinforcement that requires additional expensive building infrastructure. This limits usage of CT in more applications and more locations. For example, lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths in the USA and the world (>125,000 deaths per year in USA, 1 in 5 cancer deaths), yet only has 4.5% early screening rate using the standard method of low dose chest CT imaging to spot early cancer growths when they are treatable. A portable, accessible CT imaging system outside the hospital could expand early screening to millions of healthy but at-risk patients for diseases such as lung cancer. This especially impacts underserved rural and poor populations who do not have the means to travel to hospitals to perform early screening. X-Sight’s NSF SBIR Phase I results support building these next generation CT imaging systems to serve the broader impact mission of improving national health and saving lives. During NSF SBIR Phase I funded development work, X-Sight discovered the new distributed x-ray source imaging architecture could have additional benefits for next generation security systems to detect chemical threat signatures or portable security systems that cannot be done with conventional technology. Additionally, such architecture could enable faster automated 3D defect detection in product assembly lines, to ensure high speed and high quality USA manufacturing.
